Asha was being bullied about her height in school. The concerned parents bring her to thepediatrician who plots the growth chart as shown below. On evaluation, growth hormonelevels are found to be high and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among thefollowing could be a cause?Height (cm)Name- Ashacm1601551501451401351301251201151101051009590858075706560555045O246(0
questions.explanation: The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels pointtowards Laron syndrome/dwarfism. It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone (GHinsensitivity) due to the GH receptor mutation. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinicalfeatures as those seen in pituitary dwarfism.Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting andstimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low.In Turner's syndrome (Option A), loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated indwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, anddecreased utilization.Pituitary dwarfism (Option B) is a condition with GH deficiency.Maternal deprivation dwarfism (Option D) is due to psychosocial causes such as emotionaldeprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanismis not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rulesthis out.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormonedeficiency?

options.B: Mutations of c-MYC geneMutations of WT-1 gened) Mutations of PROP1 geneQuestion 4:You come across a child with growth hormone deficiency during your ward rounds. Which ofthe following features would you not expect in this child?a) History of short stature at birthb) High-pitched voice

questions.explanation: The most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormone deficiencies(MPHD)/panhypopituitarism is the mutation of the PROP1 gene.LHX3 and GLI2 are other genes involved in MPHD.GNAS1 mutations cause McCune Albright Syndrome.c-MYC gene is mutated in Burkitt's lymphomaWT-1 gene is mutated in Wilms tumors.

questions.question: You are evaluating children with short stature on whether they are eligible to receive growthhormone therapy as per FDA guidelines. In which of the following children would youprescribe it?

options.A: An 8 year old with Laron dwarfism
options.B: A neonate diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism
options.C: A 7 year old with Chronic kidney disease
options.D: A 6 year old diagnosed with Maternal deprivation dwarfism

questions.explanation: Chronic kidney disease is an FDA-approved indication for growth hormone (GH) therapy.Renal failure is a state of GH resistance. Moderate-to-severe growth retardation in chronic kidneydisease is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. GH therapy with recombinantgrowth hormone has been shown to improve catch-up growth and to allow the child to achievenormal adult height; the final adult height is still significantly below the genetic target.FDA-approved indications for growth hormone (GH) treatment-⚫ GH deficiency••Turner's Syndrome• Chronic Renal Failure before Transplantation• Small for Gestational Age / Short Stature• Idiopathic Short Stature.• Noonan Syndrome• Prader-Willi Syndrome• AIDS-related wasting• Malabsorption associated with the short-bowel syndrome

questions.question: Chotu, a 5-year-old boy is on regular outpatient follow-up for growth hormone deficiencydiagnosed 2 weeks back. He is planned for recombinant growth hormone therapy. All of thefollowing are possible side effects except-
questions.explanation: The use of recombinant growth hormone is associated with the risk of type 2 diabetesmellitus (not type 1 diabetes mellitus).Other adverse effects:• Pseudotumor cerebri•Slipped capital femoral epiphysis623• Gynecomastia• Worsening of scoliosisChildren who have been treated with rhGH have a higher risk of developing hemorrhagic strokesin adulthood.Some studies show an increased risk of new neoplasms in cancer survivors.

questions.explanation: The most commonly diagnosed adenomas during childhood are prolactinoma >corticotropinoma > somatotropinoma.Note:Hypothalamic hamartomas that secrete excess gonadotropin-releasing hormone can causeprecocious puberty.

questions.question: Akash is the tallest kid in his 5th-grade class. While at a routine visit for a boosterimmunization, his pediatrician plots his height on a growth chart and finds him to be above3-SD for his age. Which of the following can be an endocrine cause for his height?
questions.explanation: McCune-Albright syndrome (endocrine dysfunction affecting multiple glands) is an endocrinecause of tall stature in childhood. questions.question: "Weak giants" are produced by
questions.explanation: McCune-Albright syndromePrecocious pubertyHyperthyroidism624"Weak giants" are due to hyperpituitarism that is most commonly produced by pituitaryadenomas.Hyperpituitarism causes growth hormone (GH) excess, leading to tall stature (giants) with weakmuscles. Overproduction of GH results in gigantism in children (before fusion of bone growthplate) and acromegaly in adults.Clinical features include:Gigantism, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones• Proximal myopathy (though there is muscle hypertrophy, it is weakened due to atrophy of type IImuscle fibers)• Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues)• Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver,spleen, kidney, and prostate• Local effects of the adenoma: Headache, visual field defects, raised ICTNote: Although hypothalamic hamartomas can also produce gigantism, the most common causeof gigantism is pituitary adenomas.

questions.question: A young boy is diagnosed to have central diabetes insipidus. A lesion in which of the followingnuclei is likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation: Lesions in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus can cause centraldiabetes insipidus.These nuclei synthesize vasopressin, a 9-amino-acid peptide with antidiuretic and vascularpressor activity. It is transported to the posterior pituitary via axonal projections, where it isstored for release into the systemic circulation.Diabetes insipidus (DI) is characterized by pathologic polyuria and polydipsia (>2 L/m²/24 hr or5 mL/kg/hr). It can result from either:• Vasopressin deficiency (decreased anti-diuretic hormone production) causes central DI.• Vasopressin insensitivity at the level of the kidney causes nephrogenic DI.

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his mother with new-onset nocturnal bedwetting. She alsoreported, he has been drinking more water for the last 3-4 months. 24-hour urine volume was4 liters and the urine osmolality was low. ADH assays recorded a value was 0.7 pg/mL. Tıweighted MRI brain indicated an absence of a pituitary bright spot. What is the treatment ofchoice for his condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The treatment of choiceis desmopressin. It is a vasopressin analog (V2 receptor agonist). It can be administeredintranasally, or subcutaneously.Option A: Leuprolide is a GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) analog used in the treatmentof prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis.Option B: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drug of choice.They are generally used in nephrogenic DI.625Option D: Terlipressin is a long-acting analog on vasopressin that acts on V1 receptors of vascularsmooth muscle. It is used as a vasopressor in shock and acute variceal bleeding.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy diagnosed with Wolfram syndrome is admitted to the pediatric ward of yourhospital. Which of the following features would you expect to find in this child?
questions.explanation: Optic Atrophy is seen in Wolfram syndrome. The components of the syndrome are represented bythe acronym DIDMOAD:• Diabetes Insipidus••• Diabetes Mellitus (type 1)• Optic Atrophy• Neural DeafnessIt is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

questions.question: While working in a tertiary care center, a 5-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia,and nocturnal enuresis for the past 1 year. A water deprivation test is done and shows lowurine osmolality on stopping the intake of water. On desmopressin administration, there is a7% rise in urine osmolality. The treatment of this condition uses all of the following except?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The treatment includespharmacological treatment combined with salt restriction and not increased salt intake.Treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:•Adequate water intake along with a low sodium diet•Thiazide diuretics: Acts by• Volume contraction and increases the responsiveness of other parts of the tubule• Increase the AQP2 channels independent of vasopressin•⚫ Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice forlithium-induced DI• Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin)626
